reviews.review_msg: lectures were fun but kinda hard to understand. worst part of class was during the final exam the etchers were talking during it, not a whisper but a conversation volume. unclear instructors for the essay, there was no rubric and my feedback on it was " did not follow rubric" but there was no rubric other than the powerpoint which I followed

Fun lectures, but lacks clarity for assignments-- this evidently dropped my grade because he didn't explain what he is looking for even when I asked. He also never explained about his "quiz" portion of the class, nor did he say when they'll be up. Syllabus says quizzes are 24 hours long, but they're until midnight the same day.
very knowledgeable and passionate about his topics. wants you to actually read all of his readings but is always accessible during office hours to talk.
A lot of readings, but they are very relevant to the discussions and exams.
Very passionate, genuinely interested in the subject hes teaching.

I got along with dimitrios, but I wouldn't take him again. Strict rules like no absences, participation and deadlines. Yet it comes down to writing a good essay. So if you're trying to get the credit and you're not the best writer then don't take this course cause others will still get a better mark even if they skip every class and you don't.

I took an introduction the Greek World and loved this course. It was a joint venture taught by 4 professors but Dimitri was the main one. He's extremely passionate about the subject and I thoroughly enjoyed his lectures. He's a tough professor in a good way. You won't get by just reciting memorized lines, you'll have to read and think critically.
I have never been so confused in my life. Please do not take classes with this guy, it is not worth the stress. Basically, he is hard to understand and his lectures are confusing and disorganized.
Hard to understand. Likes to talk and get you to talk

Also took HIST 308 and 317 with him. He is a really good prof if you are willing to pay attention. He is a tough marker but if you go to office hours and go through your essay ideas he will help you a lot. Definitely a tough prof for non-History majors.

He marks hard but if you're interested in a specific topic, talk to him about it and he'll tell you to write a paper about it. In such cases he marks very generously. I found that his accent and enthusiasm adds to the flavour of the course.

Dimitri is very helpful and a fantastic lecturer. He is very passionate about the topic, and his slides show interesting photos. But, he is a very hard marker! You can do well if you follow his comments and visit him in office hours. This class is challenging but worth it because you learn a ton! Be prepared to work hard for your grade!!

Krallis has good lectures and he encourages active participation in tutorials. He never uses the textbook. He marks the essays (there are only 3) very critically so you will probably not get very high marks if you are a poor essay writer.
I've never had such a bad history prof. To all my fellow students don't take a class with this guy.

Professor Krallis is a difficult marker. He did not give me back my last paper with feedback which is disappointing. Attendance in lectures and tutorials are mandatory. He is very knowledgeable about Greek/Byzantine history.

Lectures are not clearly defined. He likes to jump back and forth from one time period to another. History department really needs to have someone sit in on one of his class and see how bad he really is.

Anyone who didn't like him or didn't find him helpful is an idiot. Yes he's a bit challenging and Byzantine history isn't for everyone, but if you put in some decent work and interest in the course you'll do fine. I've taken 3 classes with him now and I've done well in each one. And his English is super.
He is a very friendly and easygoing prof. People complain about his marking, but if you talk to him he will be very helpful. Take his classes if you like primary sources.

He has a high rate of interest in Byzantium. He was one of the best seminars that I ever took, although the material could be dry he usually found a way to make it more interesting. His marking is fair and if you need help or clarification he is approachable.

He's very difficult to understand and he has very high expectations for term papers. His lectures are poorly orgamized and he does not stay on topic. Someone from the history department should really be monitoring him and his teaching style. Worst prof in the department.
Great prof, clearly loves the subject material, relates well to the students and is always available to help the students when they need it
Dimitri is an engaging prof who is well versed in his subject.  He's always willing to help, and a fair marker. Took this class on his field school, and would definately recommend him.
One good thing about Gordon Campbell being re-elected is that he'll be cutting post secondary funding which means that Dimitrious will be one of the first to be fired!

If you avoid stereotypes and vague generalizations when analyzing primary sources, you should manage to submit B-/B papers. His marking scheme is up to par with how most History profs mark at the upper level. Just take time in writing/analyzing the sources.

The Greece Field School is great because you get to go to Greece but Dimitrios will be on vacation so don't expect him to be available to you.  He won't deal with any of your concerns, so be prepared to live with problems or sort them out yourself. Overall he's prettey useless.
can be a litttle hard to understand at first. Uses a lot of primary documents, teaches you how to get the most out of them. Marking was reasonable.

His constant use of primary sources helps anyone pursuing a history degree gain valuable skills. The course is interesting and he himself is a great lecturer. However, he will make you work for your marks. Don't expect an easy A. Most people fell in the C-C+ range on papers. But if you consider his comments you will do well and pass.
Not bad. I'm not a history student but I took this class as part of the Greece field school and still managed to do ok...it was worth it for Greece.

took this class on my field school in greece.. he was extremely flexible and was always available (at the beach bar) if you had any questions.. his class was hard and a lot of work but then again it was 4 months of classwork crammed into less than 2 months.. awesome and hilarious guy!

Dimitri is a great, wonderful, helpful person who will probably become a great prof - in the future. Right now, he's still too new to it. Essay q's were a bit vague. He compares the US and Bush to the Romans a LOT. Bottom line, though, is that compared to my interest level (extremely high) this course disappointed me.
Bit of problem understanding him in class. Is not clear with what he wants in his assignments. Gives to much reading that is not relevent to his lectures.
This was the worst history class i've ever taken. Needs to go easy on the marking, this only an undergrad class. He is not helping to attract students to the hellenic studies program.
teacher is interesting and funny. i have taken 2 classes with him, and would definitely take more. he likes to use primary sources.

Horrible professor.  Like someone said, he marks like we're doing our PHD's.  I don't know anyone who is happy with him.  The language barrier is a problem.  I was also shocked to hear him spout **** remarks and then joke "don't quote me on this".  I will never take him again.  His comments on papers are harsh and the topics are nonsensical.

This is could have been a very interesting class but Dimitios just sucks the life out of it. He is more interested in filling a hour and a half session than actually teaching. And his grading is far to difficult. He's a nice guy but if you care about your gpa, don't take one of his classes

He was a good prof, interesting and approachable. He did assign a lot of reading and it was impossible to keep up, however he himself realized that as well near the end of the semester.. textbook, well i never opened it and still did failry well but essays were marked very tough, and he expected a very high caliber.
He thinks History has only one answer. This is not math
Dmitri rocked! If you are having some trouble just go have a chat with him.This guy made me LOVE Byzantine history.
he needs it realize that you are not grading phd papers

Roman and Byzantine history has always interested me, but Krallis is not organized in teaching it. I found myself lost during sum of the lectures. Good text book though. I would have been better off just buying the textbook and not bothered to take the class.

The history of Rome and Byzantium and interesting to study, but unfortunately not with Dimitrios. The textbook is the only useful study tool in this class as his lectures and the course pack are not useful. He is very picking when it comes to grading, even for a history prof. All 2007 Greece field school students should be aware of this as he will

Over all, great class. Dimitri has a refreshing sense of humour, and is well versed in Byzantine history. Try not to 'force the tyrant' to come out in him, by showing up to tutorial having not done your readings. Very approachable if you are having troubles following his lectures or materials.
He assigns a lot of readings.
